The secant series ((LABEL:eq:EF.CI.CX)) first occurs in the work of Gregory in 1671.

paragraph.title: Polynomials and Numbers of Integer Order

para.sentence: For \ell=0,1,2,\ldots , Bernoulli and Euler polynomials of order \ell are defined respectively by \left(\frac{t}{e^{t}-1}\right)^{\ell}e^{xt}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B^{(\ell)}_{n} \left(x\right)\frac{t^{n}}{n!}, subject to |t|<2\pi, , \left(\frac{2}{e^{t}+1}\right)^{\ell}e^{xt}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}E^{(\ell)}_{n} \left(x\right)\frac{t^{n}}{n!}, subject to |t|<\pi.
When x=0 they reduce to the Bernoulli and Euler numbers of order \ell : B^{(\ell)}_{n}=B^{(\ell)}_{n}\left(0\right), E^{(\ell)}_{n}=E^{(\ell)}_{n}\left(0\right).
Also for \ell=1,2,3,\ldots , \left(\frac{\ln\left(1+t\right)}{t}\right)^{\ell}=\ell\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac {B^{(\ell+n)}_{n}}{\ell+n}\frac{t^{n}}{n!}, subject to |t|<1.
For this and other properties see ( , pp. 126–153) or ( , pp. 144–162) .
For extensions of B^{(\ell)}_{n}\left(x\right) to complex values of x , n , and \ell , and also for uniform asymptotic expansions for large x and large n , see ( ) and ( ) .

Let \chi be a primitive Dirichlet character \mod f (see §LABEL:sec:NT.DIR).
Then f is called the conductor of \chi.

Generalized Bernoulli numbers and polynomials belonging to \chi are defined by \sum_{a=1}^{f}\frac{\chi(a)te^{at}}{e^{ft}-1}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n,\chi} \frac{t^{n}}{n!} , B_{n,\chi}(x)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}{n\choose k}B_{k,\chi}x^{n-k}.
Let \chi_{0} be the trivial character and \chi_{4} the unique (nontrivial) character with f=4 ; that is, \chi_{4}(1)=1 , \chi_{4}(3)=-1 , \chi_{4}(2)=\chi_{4}(4)=0.
Then B_{n}\left(x\right)=B_{n,\chi_{0}}(x-1), E_{n}\left(x\right)=-\frac{2^{1-n}}{n+1}B_{n+1,\chi_{4}}(2x-1).
For further properties see ( ) .

Let 0\leq h\leq 1 and a,m , and n be integers such that n>a , m>0 , and f^{(m)}(x) is absolutely integrable over [a,n].

Then with the notation of § LABEL:sec:BP.DE.PBEF \sum_{j=a}^{n-1}(-1)^{j}f(j+h)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{k=0}^{m-1}\frac{E_{k}\left(h \right)}{k!}\left((-1)^{n-1}f^{(k)}(n)+(-1)^{a}f^{(k)}(a)\right)+R_{m}(n) , where R_{m}(n)=\frac{1}{2(m-1)!}\int_{a}^{n}f^{(m)}(x)\widetilde{E}_{m-1}\left(h-x \right)\mathrm{d}x.
For a more modern perspective see ( ) .
Let \mathcal{S}_{n} denote the class of functions that have n-1 continuous derivatives on \mathbb{R} and are polynomials of degree at most n in each interval (k,k+1) , k\in\mathbb{Z}.
The members of \mathcal{S}_{n} are calledcardinal spline functions.

The functions S_{n}(x)=\frac{\widetilde{E}_{n}\left(x+\tfrac{1}{2}n+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)}{ \widetilde{E}_{n}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}n+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)}, subject to n=0,1,\dots, are called Euler splines of degree n.
For each n , S_{n}(x) is the unique bounded function such that S_{n}(x)\in\mathcal{S}_{n} and S_{n}(k)=(-1)^{k}, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}.
The function S_{n}(x) is also optimal in a certain sense; see ( ) .
A function of the form x^{n}-S(x) , with S(x)\in\mathcal{S}_{n-1} is called a cardinal monospline of degree n.

Again with the notation of §LABEL:sec:BP.DE.PBEF define M_{n}(x)=\begin{cases}\widetilde{B}_{n}\left(x\right)-B_{n},&n\text{ even},\\ \widetilde{B}_{n}\left(x+\frac{1}{2}\right),&n\text{ odd}.\end{cases } M_{n}(x) is a monospline of degree n , and it follows from (LABEL:eq:BP.EL.SPB1) and (LABEL:eq:BP.EL.SPB2) that M_{n}(k)=0, subject to k\in\mathbb{Z}.

For each n=1,2,\dots the function M_{n}(x) is also the unique cardinal monospline of degree n satisfying (LABEL:eq:BP.SP.BE2), provided that M_{n}(x)=O\left(|x|^{\gamma}\right), subject to x\to\pm\infty, for some positive constant \gamma.

For any n\geq 2 the function F(x)=\widetilde{B}_{n}\left(x\right)-2^{-n}B_{n} is the unique cardinal monospline of degree n having the least supremum norm \|F\|_{\infty} on \mathbb{R} (minimality property).

Bernoulli and Euler numbers and polynomials occur in: number theory via (LABEL:eq:BP.EL.SUB1), (LABEL:eq:BP.EL.SUE1), and other identities involving sums of powers; the Riemann zeta function and L -series (§LABEL:sec:ZE.DIR, ( ) , and ( ) ); arithmetic of cyclotomic fields and the classical theory of Fermat’s last theorem ( ( ) and ( ) ); p -adic analysis ( ( , Chapter 2) ).
Bernoulli polynomials appear in statistical physics ( ( ) ), in discussions of Casimir forces ( ( ) ), and in a study of quark-gluon plasma ( ( ) ).
Euler polynomials also appear in statistical physics as well as in semi-classical approximations to quantum probability distributions ( ( ) ).

para.sentence: Equations (LABEL:eq:BP.LI.BAB2) and (LABEL:eq:BP.LI.BAE2) enable B_{n} and E_{n} to be computed by recurrence.
For higher values of n more efficient methods are available.

For example, the tangent numbers T_{n} can be generated by simple recurrence relations obtained from (LABEL:eq:BP.RE.TA1), then (LABEL:eq:BP.RE.TA2) is applied. A similar method can be used for the Euler numbers based on (LABEL:eq:EF.CI.CX).

For number-theoretic applications it is important to compute B_{2n}\pmod{p} for 2n\leq p-3 ; in particular to find theirregular pairs (2n,p) for which B_{2n}\equiv 0\pmod{p}.
We list here three methods, arranged in increasing order of efficiency.
( ) derives a congruence \pmod{p} for Bernoulli numbers in terms of sums of powers.
See also §LABEL:sec:BP.AR.VO.
( ) uses the expansion \frac{t^{2}}{\cosh t-1}=-2\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(2n-1)B_{2n}\frac{t^{2n}}{(2n)!} , and computes inverses modulo p of the left-hand side.
Multisectioning techniques are applied in implementations.
See also ( , pp. 116–120) .
A method related to “Stickelberger codes” is applied in ( ) ; in particular, it allows for an efficient search for the irregular pairs (2n,p).
Discrete Fourier transforms are used in the computations.
